Award.AwardTitle: CSR--EHS: Small: Limited-information control of hybrid systems via reachable set propagation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The theme of this project is control of hybrid systems based on limited (sampled and quantized) information about their state. The project aims to bring together, for the first time, two research topics: hybrid systems, and control with limited information. The project will seek to develop a novel method for propagating over-approximations of reachable sets for hybrid systems, and use it to define and validate a control strategy based on sampled and quantized measurements of the continuous state. This method will be combined with state-of-the-art analysis tools for hybrid and switched systems, such as multiple Lyapunov functions, average dwell-time switching, and input-to-state stability.

Hybrid systems are important for modeling and controlling the behavior of cyber-physical systems, such as fly-by-wire aircraft and power grids. Hybrid systems combine continuous dynamics and discrete transitions. This hybrid nature enables one to capture many processes encountered in practice which switch between different modes of operation. Controllers for such systems typically have limited information about the system state, due to limitations of available sensors and delays and losses in communication. A possible scenario is controlling an autonomous robot which switches between the search mode and the pursuit mode and, for security or implementation cost reasons, is connected to the control center via a very low-power communication link. Educational and outreach activities of the project include support of a graduate student, integration of the research with graduate courses in hybrid systems and control, workshops and short courses, and involvement of undergraduates in translating theoretical developments into software tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project was devoted to control of switched and hybrid systems based on limited (sampled and quantized) information about their state. Several fundamental theoretical results have been obtained in limited-information control (including control of switched systems in the presence of disturbances); small-gain theorems for switched and hybrid systems; nonlinear controllability; adaptive control; and stability of switched systems and of general nonlinear systems.

The problem of limited-information control of hybrid systems is attractive because of the rich theoretical research possibilities that it opens. The questions of how much information is really needed to solve a given control problem, or what interesting control tasks can be performed with a given amount of information, are quite fundamental from the theoretical point of view. A novel combination of technical tools from hybrid systems and nonlinear control theory has been developed to study these questions, and the results will likely generate high interest in both communities.

This work is expected to have significant impact on applications. The hybrid nature of the system enables one to capture many processes encountered in practice which switch between different modes of operation, while the limited nature of the communication between the system and the controller allows one to incorporate scenarios where the controller is remotely located or the sensors are limited. Combining the two aspects, we have contributed to developing a unified framework for building and analyzing control systems capable of handling realistic dynamics and realistic control architectures.


The work supported by this grant has resulted in 9 journal articles and 17 conference publications. The grant provided partial support for three graduate students. The PI has given one plenary lecture, two semi-plenary lectures, and numerous invited lectures and conference presentations. For his research accomplishments, the PI was elected IEEE Fellow in 2013 and IFAC Fellow in 2016.
